case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 303 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 303 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 10 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Incometax Reference No. 10 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on May 4, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. May 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated August 3, 1956, in a reference under s. 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the Appellate Tribunal, Bombay.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Com- missioner of Income-tax, Bombay City, is the appellant, and the Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd., Bombay,  the assessee Company , is the respondent.

facts.text: Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd., Bombay is the assessee Company and respondent.

anchor.surface_text: the Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd., Bombay,  the assessee Company , is the respondent. The assessee Company has its year of account ending June 30 every year.

facts.text: Assessee Company's year of account ends June 30 every year.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company has its year of account ending June 30 every year.

facts.text: At close of account year 1951, assessee carried forward profits of Rs. 30,680.

anchor.surface_text: At the close of the account year 1951, it carried forward profits amounting to Rs. 30,680.

facts.text: In account year 1951, assessee earned rebate by declaring dividends below limit fixed by Finance Act.

anchor.surface_text: In that year, it appears it had earned a rebate by declaring dividends below the limit fixed by the Finance Act.

facts.text: For account year 1952, book profits were Rs. 28,67,235 less allowances for depreciation and tax.

anchor.surface_text: For the account year 1952 its book profits were Rs. 28,67,235 less allowances for depreciation and tax.

facts.text: After adjustments, balance available for distribution in 1952 was Rs. 5,02,915.

anchor.surface_text: After these and other sundry adjustments, the balance available for distribution was Rs. 5,02,915.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer found total income for 1952 as Rs. 5,26,681.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that the Incometax Officer on processing the income found the total income to be Rs. 5,26,681.

facts.text: For account year 1952, assessee declared dividends of Rs. 4,78,950.

anchor.surface_text: For the account year 1952, the assessee Company declared dividends amounting to Rs. 4,78,950 and carried forward the balance of Rs. 23,965.

facts.text: Carried forward balance in 1952 was Rs. 23,965.

anchor.surface_text: and carried forward the balance of Rs. 23,965. We are companycerned with the assessment year 1953-54, and the Finance Act, 1953, is applicable.

facts.text: Concerned with assessment year 1953-54, Finance Act 1953 applicable.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the assessment year 1953-54, and the Finance Act, 1953, is applicable. That Finance Act applied the Finance Act, 1951, with some changes.

facts.text: Finance Act 1953 applied Finance Act 1951 with some changes.

anchor.surface_text: That Finance Act applied the Finance Act, 1951, with some changes. The Finance Act, 1953, with the modifications will be referred to briefly, hereinafter, as the Finance Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer found assessee declared excess dividends of Rs. 1,87,691.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer found that the assessee Company had declared excess dividends amounting to Rs. 1,87,691.

facts.text: Additional income-tax calculated on excess dividends at 5 annas per rupee after deductions, amounting to Rs. 21,115-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: He calculated additional income-tax on it at 5 annas in the rupee after deducting income-tax borne by the profits of the previous year at 4 annas per rupee, a surcharge of 5 per cent. less rebate of one anna in the rupee as allowed by the Finance Act. This additional tax amounted to Rs. 21,115-4-0.

facts.text: Appeals of assessee Company under Income-tax Act failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals of the assessee Company under the Income-tax Act failed.

facts.text: Tribunal held excess dividends deemed paid out of undistributed profits of year ending June 30, 1951, Rs. 6,60,720 on which rebate of 1 anna given in assessment year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the excess dividends were deemed to be paid out of undistributed profits of earlier year ending June 30, 1951, amounting to Rs. 6,60,720 on which a rebate of 1 anna in the rupee was given in the assessment year, 1952-53.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred four questions to High Court under s.66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated August 3, 1956, in a reference under s. 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the Appellate Tribunal, Bombay. The Tribunal referred four questions for the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: First question not pressed before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Tile Tribunal observed that additional incometax was also a tax on income, and that the Finance Act companyld say that the tax would be payable on the income of any year preceding the previous year.

facts.text: High Court answered remaining questions in the negative after modifying them.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number answer the first question because it was number pressed, and answered the remaining in the negative, after modifying them.

facts.text: High Court certified case fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: It has certified this case as fit for appeal to this Court, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Before High Court, it was conceded that Finance Act provisions had to come within scope of s.3 of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that before the High Court it was companyceded that in order that the provisions of the Finance Act might be effective, the Finance Act had to companye within the scope of s. 3 of the Incometax Act.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: This question was answered by the High Court in the negative. In the opinion of the High Court, s. 3 of the Indian Income- tax Act lays down the liability to tax, and it puts the tax on the total income of the previous year.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court was right in answering the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was right in answering the question which it had framed, in the negative.
under s. 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the Appellate Tribunal, Bombay.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court right in negative answer

holdings.text: The High Court was right in answering the question in the negative: additional income-tax has not been legally charged under clause (ii) of the proviso to paragraph B of Part 1 of the First Schedule to the Indian Finance Act, 1951, as applied to the assessment year 1953-54 by the Indian Finance Act, 1953, read with Section 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we are of opinion that the High Court was right in answering the question which it had framed, in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finance Act imposes additional tax on excess dividends deemed from past undistributed profits but fails to deem those profits part of total income of previous year under s.3 IT Act, which charges tax only on income of previous year; fiction limited to calculating tax shortfall borne by past profits.

holdings.text: Provisions of the Finance Act for additional income-tax on excess dividends go beyond the ambit and scope of the Indian Income-tax Act, particularly s.3.

anchor.surface_text: s. 3 of the Indian Income- tax Act lays down the liability to tax, and it puts the tax on the total income of the previous year. The method of computing this total income is also to be found in the Finance Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3 limits charge to total income of previous year; Finance Act targets accumulated past profits without integrating into current total income, exceeding s.3 scope.

holdings.text: Additional income-tax cannot be levied, assessed and recovered under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether additional income-tax can be levied, assessed and recovered under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No independent levy possible without fitting within s.3 charge on previous year's total income; Finance Act dependent on IT Act framework.

holdings.text: Additional income-tax has not been legally charged under the Indian Finance Act, 1953, read with the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether at any rate the additional income-tax has been legally charged under the Indian Finance Act, 1953, read with the Indian Income-tax Act?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even read together, Finance Act does not align with s.3 requirement of taxing total income of previous year.

holdings.text: The Finance Act cannot impose additional income-tax independently of Section 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that before the High Court it was conceded that in order that the provisions of the Finance Act might be effective, the Finance Act had to come within the scope of s. 3 of the Incometax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded and accepted; Finance Act rates apply to income charged under s.3 IT Act, cannot create independent charge.

holdings.text: The court cannot modify or recast the language of the Finance Act to sustain the tax independently of s.3.

anchor.surface_text: Other arguments involved modifications of language suitable to sustain the tax independently of s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, a procedure which we do not think is open, for reasons which we have given in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial function is interpretation as stands, not legislative rewriting; follows precedent in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957.

holdings.text: The statutory fiction deeming excess dividend out of undistributed profits of preceding years does not make such profits part of the total income of the previous year under assessment.

anchor.surface_text: the excess dividend shall be deemed to be out of the whole or such portion of the undistributed profits of one or more years immediately preceding the previous year... This fiction... provides only that the dividends shall be deemed to be out of the profits not of the previous year under assessment but of some other years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction operates only for determining tax borne by excess (rate calculation); no deeming provision integrates past profits into current total income for chargeability under s.3.

holdings.text: Income-tax Act charges tax only on total income of the previous year or what is deemed to be such income thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Chief Justice, with respect, very rightly pointed out that the Income-tax Act puts the tax on income or something which it deems to be income. In other words, the tax deals with income and income only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax base strictly limited to previous year's income; Finance Act rates apply thereto, cannot extend to past years without specific deeming into total income.

anchor.surface_text: a procedure which we do number think is open, for reasons which we have given in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957, decided today. These modifications,
